Comment: Good variation of the original puzzle, lgtm

It looks good to me but I wonder, why does it need Python conventions ?
It lacks of consistency, as there is not always parentheses.
I believe the use of i instead of j would be more natural as this is the letter you use most of the time in maths.
A zero, even if complex, should be written 0 and not 0j.

So I understand the rules of Python and I was able to deal with them, but why ?

Comment: Interesting version of Euclid's algorithm
The process of euclidean division for complex number is well explained, it's easy to solve when you know the algorithm for real numbers.
While the reaction to this has seemed rather indifferent, I still want to submit it since I don't see what I could change to make it better. As always, feedback is appreciated.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Good idea. Codingame needs more complex-related puzzles

Changed the difficulty from medium to easy because I saw that the version alluded in the statement has a 90% success rate in the easy category and this is honestly not significantly harder.

Feedback appreciated.

I first went with Math.Round in C# and was failing test 4 since my code went with -2 for -1.5 instead of -1.  When I switched to your "Closest" logic it passed.  Convention would dictate that the closest integer of -1.5 is -2 if I'm not mistaken.

But I enjoyed this very much.  I did it with the .Net Complex struct and my own implementation.  Both worked fine.

In C# it's easy enough to create a formatting function or override ToString if you are creating your own Complex number struct.

The hardest part of this is to find a format that suits all languages (and not stuff like 0j for 0 in python). 

Atm it follows the python conventions for printing complex numbers. 

So I inflicted myself the task of solving it in cpp (with probably many idiomatic mistakes along the way). Wasn't the best of ideas. Literally >50% of the solution is formatting...

I'd like to know the opinion of non python people about this one before I add the input, constraints, more tests etc.

Basically how annoying it is to print out your solution in the required format. And if you have any ideas about how to fix it.

The existing format is visually simple to understand. I guess the choice is between a simpler format and a more complex format.

One way to simplify the format a bit and make it less Python-like is using just brackets with or without commas. Examples:
(-6 27)     (-6,27)
[-6 27]     [-6,27]
{-6 27}     {-6,27}
<-6 27>     <-6,27>

(Well, some of the formats still are Python-like in some other ways...)

Or even:
|-6 27|     |-6,27|
`-6 27`     `-6,27`
#-6 27#     #-6,27#
... etc. you get the idea :wink:

Thanks for your feedback.

Now for the rounding convention I agree that the statement is insufficient and I'm going to change this. I thought "If x = 1/2, pick 1." was enough but the more I think the more I realize it's probably unclear.

I was aware of that rounding issue but I haven't tested deep enough to see if the rounding can mess up with certain languages. I know that 

print(round(2.5)) = 2 (python)

but

p (2.5).round = 3 (ruby)

so I decided to go with that "convention". Rounding gives a valid algorithm too but there's no guarantee that the solutions would be equal.

Will change the statement a bit + the name of test 4. Thanks.

- It needs to be solvable in every language even though every language has different conventions for printing complex numbers (and that's when they support complex numbers, unlike let's say perl)
- The main point of this puzzle was not to do some parsing, but to revisit the GCD algorithm and manipulate some complex numbers. 
- Python is by far the most used language in this site.

So I had to find a solution that catered most people, and that's what I got.

Mmh okay I guess that's a good reason.
The point isn't to do parsing and that was most of the length of my code, hence the question, maybe I should have done it in Python

Yeah, it does require quite some parsing for pretty much every language that isn't Python. I've solved in ruby, cpp, perl and ocaml and they all had (if they had) different conventions iirc. A user down in this comment section solved it in C# and it seems like it's also different there.

What is even weirder in python :
round(0.5) -> 0
round(1.5) -> 2
round(2.5) -> 2
(round takes the closest even integer in .5 cases, to avoid impacting too much when applied to a large dataset)
This can lead to confusing results when you're not using it carefully
I'll think about it, I did simplify the format logic a lot from when I wrote the first answer so now it doesn't seem so tedious to me (I think it was double the lines of code back then?).

Sure!

There's this tricky part where complex numbers in some languages (tested cpp and ocaml) are better manipulated when everything is a float (even though we just want ints). I just rechecked and if I try to force ints, this line becomes a nightmare (as in, I don't even know how to fix it...lol) :

complex<float> z =  z1 / z2;

and in ocaml it won't even let me read the complex numbers lol

  let parse_complex x y = { re = x; im = y } in

  let z1 = sf (read_line()) "%d %d" parse_complex in
  let z2 = sf (read_line()) "%d %d" parse_complex in

Error: This expression has type float -> float -> Complex.t
       but an expression was expected of type int -> int -> 'a
       Type float is not compatible with type int 

As a side note it makes no difference for python:

z1 = complex(*map(int, input().split()))
or
z1 = complex(*map(float, input().split()))

give the same result for my solution.

So while they are integers I will rather parse them as floats by default, I do agree that it's weird but yeah...

Also, what did you mean by: 

Goal section
* Please change "x +iy" to "x + iy".

I see.

And I mean a missing space in the expression.

And in relation to the "int"/"float" issue in the stub generator, my view is that it will be the coder's job to convert an integer to a float if needed. In addition, is it a must for other language users to use the default complex number library to solve the puzzle? In other words, is it possible to solve the puzzle using just integers and other approaches (especially for the languages you mentioned)?

This is what it becomes if you don't want to use a complex library (Perl).

https://bpa.st/2QQC4

That's like the worse scenario in my book lol. Everything is in here: https://github.com/daxida/CodinGame-contributions/tree/main/euclid-complex

(Also I will address your previous suggestions eventually)

Understood what the code may look like if not using a standard library. Thanks. üëç

If my understanding is correct, it is possible to solve the puzzle without converting the inputs to floats, as shown by your code. While the job may be much easier by using the standard library, the author need not take care to make sure the parsed variables are of the type most convenient to the coder.

**Consistency with the statement is sufficient.**

That's the main rationale behind my comment on the stub generator.

Some related points:

‚Ä¢ In most cases, the author should not prescribe the approach on how to solve the puzzle for the player. (I know that is not your intention.)

‚Ä¢ It is easy for the coders to write a few lines of code to convert integers into floats if they want to / if they feel it is necessary. It's their choice.

‚Ä¢ Such conversion is not required for ALL languages. I may equally argue that the conversion to floats means (a little bit) more code is needed when formatting the output, as either conversion back to integers or formatting of floats as integers is required.

At the end of the day, you are fully entitled to make the final decision, and I would respect that. :)

Those are valid points and as such I implemented all your suggestion but the one of explaining the python formatting. 

It may seem arbitrary but I just don't want to make the statement twice as long, especially when i suspect that most people will do as I did, and tinker their code on the fly according to the tests results. 

I made sure that every formatting detail appeared on the tests (including the very random -0j, tested on test3 + validator 4) so it should be fine in my opinion.

Thanks and glad to know! :D

That's why I suggested to include a reference only, not a full explanation, exactly because I share the same thought as you :wink:

Or it will make explanation easier if a simpler format like the ones I suggested before is adopted.

(Simplicity is also the reason why I suggested to delete "in the suitable format. This puzzle follows the Python conventions for printing complex numbers." in Output section. Avoid repetition and keep Output section away from more explanation than necessary. :wink: )
